page.title: 17PEAT-FUEL FOR BURNING 1/2
page.content: Large parts of Whalsay are covered with peat.The peat varies in depth from under a metre to over 4 metres. The surface of the moor has heather and grasses.Many people on the island use peat as a fuel for heating their houses,even running central heating systems from a peat-burning fire. The places where peat is 'cast' or cut from a peat bank.First the surface vegetation or 'fields' are cut off and set down in the bottom of the bank,the 'greff'.A tool called a tushkar is then used to cut the peat.This is a one man job.As the peat is cut it is thrown on the top of the bank.If there is deep enough peat a 2nd. peat may be cut,this will be built into an open dyke.The peat is then left to dry, shrinking as it does.After a week or two,depending on the weather,the peat will be'raised',built up into heaps.
